author: ra226
title: A great model with even greater potential
review:
Look and Articulation

Bastion is immediately recognizable in his robot form and looks great.  His Omnic Crisis color scheme looks fantastic and I love that they went with this skin over the default.  This skin also happens to be my favorite Bastion skin and it's what I run when I play the game, so I may be slightly biased there.  He's quite posable, with ball joints at his head, shoulders, hips, and ankles, and hinges at his elbows and non-rifle wrist.  His knees, unfortunately, are completely fixed--more on that later...  He also has a few other assorted joints at his cannon, heels, and shoulder panels.

Accessories

He comes with a small display stand with a Blizzard name plate attached to it as well as his bird friend, Ganymede.  The stand is a nice touch collectors will appreciate, and hopefully it means there will be more display models (and not just the minifigs we already know about) on the way.  His rifle arm has a stud-shooter mounted and comes with a few yellow 1x1 rounds to fire.  Bastion's bird friend, Ganymede, is slightly crude but still quite recognizable as a bird (in this case, a cardinal), which is pretty amazing at this scale considering he is piece-built.  He's shown perched on Bastion's shoulder, but thanks to the excellent articulation, it's easy to pose Bastion holding him up to his face while perched on his hand to have a conversation.  Including Ganymede lends a splash of color as well as personality, and softens the character of what's otherwise, let's face it, a killer robot with a huge gun.

Value

There's no way around this--Bastion is hugely overpriced.  This being a licensed set, I expected to pay more than the typical $0.10/pc, but this set has no custom printed pieces, and no collectible/exclusive minifigs--and without the benefit of free shipping, VIP points, or freebee throw-ins (the model is not available from Lego, only Blizzard), this little 182 piece set came to a painful $33 shipped.  I understand, it's an exclusive set made for a niche market, but for that much, it would have been nice to have 20 or so more pieces to give the knees hinges and make him more transformable...

Transformability

So speaking of being transformable, he's not.  At least, not in the usual sense...  You can flip him around backwards and pull his canon down, but it's not very close at all to what he looks like in game as a turret, to say nothing of tank mode.  Now if this weren't Lego, the story would end there.  What's keeping him from being transformable?  I'd say, at minimum, he needs:

  • Hinges in the knees
  • Collapsible head
  • Collapsible rifle
  • More versatile shoulders/shoulder panels
  • Better joint on the gatling gun/cannon
  • Tank treads

Now there are a lot of parts in this set.  The legs are a full five plates thick and the arms each have two hinges.  We also have the usual assortment of spare parts.  It's almost like Lego wants us to redesign him into his other two modes--or even, possibly, something that transforms properly.  I've only taken the first steps toward this (hey, I've only had him for 24 hrs as of this writing!), but what I have found is:

  • The 2x2 round on the gun barrel comes right off to reveal a very close replica of the cannon from his tank mode.
  • The shoulders almost fold up in such a way that you can create both the armor shields for turret mode as well as the ammo cannisters in tank mode.
  • The head can be pulled off the stem used for his neck and then placed back on same stem through the back instead of the bottom, leaving it in a flattened position.
  • The elbow joints on the cannon can be flipped around allowing it to swing into a much better position for a potential gun mode.  The cost of this is having the gun sit slightly farther off Bastion's back in robot mode.
  • The faceted tiles (four on each leg) look suspiciously like tank treads, and the double-set of 1x4 offset plates on the toes look like they'd make great wheels for a tank mode...

In other words, Bastion is begging to be reconfigured.  So while some might complain that he should be transformable, I would instead say this is Lego at its best--showing you the possibility, giving you the pieces you need, and leaving you to your imagination to make it happen.  I haven't played--I mean really played--with a Lego set like this in a long time.  With any luck, I hope to be editing this review and perhaps adding photos of the results of my further tinkering.
 

Final Thoughts

I love that this model even exists at all.  There are lots of Lego fans and lots of Overwatch players, but I'm not sure just how much of an intersection there is between those two groups, and yet Lego took the risk to produce this set.  It's totally overpriced... but we're talking $33 shipped vs. $23.  It's a great little set and given its niche and exclusive nature, $10 isn't that much of a premium.  I'm glad I purchased it and I love that his one glaring flaw, to my surprise, turned out to be the inspiration to be a kid again and enjoy Lego as it was meant to be.  This is the first model in a long time that's been more than just a build it and put it on display experience, and I love that.

I can't say I'll be buying tons of Overwatch sets, but Bastion here has shown me that the collaboration between Blizzard and Lego is definitely something to pay close attention to.  I'm looking forward to seeing what else they can come up with together (ahem, D.Va mech, anyone??).

Until then... Bweep, bwoop-beep!

 

UPDATE

It's been a few weeks now and the most obvious thing that's happened since this review is the release of #75974 Bastion.  The new Bastion is a little more expensive and a lot better of a model.  Converting this model into something transformable is now, sadly, rather pointless.  So I won't bother posting pictures, but I was able to modify the legs to have knee joints and reversed the hinges on his shoulders allowing the arms to fold better for turret mode (at a cost of them not quite laying flat in bot mode).

These two changes, along with quickly removing and replacing the head and shoulder panels in "partsformer" fashion (to borrow a term from the Transformers fandom) made him into a pretty decent, transformable model in both bot and turret modes.  I don't doubt I could make a pretty good looking tank mode out of the parts on hand, but that would involve a complete tear down of his legs and lower torso and would not be remotely transformable.  Even in the actual game, Bastion's treads basically come out of nowhere during his transformation so no real surprise there.

Given the existence of the newer, bigger Bastion, I've reduced the "value for money" score from 3 to 1.  It's really closer to 1.5 since he's still a decent model, but I just can't forgive how quickly another, far superior Bastion was released before this one had even barely left my hands.  On the bright side, we are getting a D.va mech I'd wished for, and it looks fantastic, so there's that.
